Mortgage Quote First Time Homebuyer - Is this a good deal and what can I negotiate?

We're submitting an offer on our first home which is a townhouse/condo.  Property is in Southern California if you're wondering why the price is so ridiculous.  Anyways, I've only reached out to one two lenders and received this quote from one of them.  This is one of our realtors preferred finance people to work with.  I have $105,000 in downpayment/closing cost funds to play with.  I'm trying to get as much of that to go towards the principal/offset the loan amount as possible.  Finance guy says he will cover the appraisal cost, but that's it.

Here's a copy of what he provided me

[https://imgur.com/a/edQYSb1](https://imgur.com/a/edQYSb1)

1. Is this a good deal?
2. What can I negotiate?

Our combined credit score is 807.  Only debt we have is my wifes Federal student loan which is $300/mo.

Paying off Car Loan Early Negative Credit Score Impact During Home Loan Shopping?

I'm in the process of buying a home but will need to wait until May/June to close.  I have a car loan that has 6 payments left on it, with the last payment due 8/1/22.  I'm in a position to just pay the loan off now, but I've heard that paying this off early could temporarily drop my credit score.  I'm at 807 credit score now and want it as high as possible at the time I lock in the loan. Thoughts?  Should I just let the loan continue?

Father Had Stroke, No Health Insurance, Nevada

**Summary**: Father is a self-employed in a skilled trade.  Had a stroke out of the blue (in his mid-50's) and does not currently have health insurance.  I've been called in (his daughter) to pick up the pieces.  He residents in Nevada and that's also where the stroke happened.  Stroke occurred during sleep.  Moderate stroke, led to a 4-day hospital stay at a County-run hospital where an MRI and numerous echos were conducted.  My dad is doing pretty well and is slowly getting back into work, but I can tell there's some residual confusion/disorientation.  He's probably 90-95% functional (based on me hanging out with him for a day or two).

**Insurance Going Forward**

My first goal here is to get him insured.  The hospital gave him two different paperwork packets.  The first is a Medicaid application.  The second is a charity care application.  According to the hospital, individuals must make $1483 or less per month to qualify for Medicaid.  My father is a sole proprietor, so he purposely keeps tabs on everything to ensure his reportable income remains as low as possible.  However, his income can fluctuate wildly though.  One month, he may make $10,000, the next month, $500.  How does this work with Medicaid?  Does some one have continuously apply and verify throughout the year?

**Paying Bills Soon to Accumulate**

Bills have not yet arrived, but we're preparing for some whoppers.  Hospital already offering a "30% discount" because he is considered "cash pay."  If he is approved for Medicaid, will Medicaid help pay for the hospital stay that already occurred retroactively?  What about if I get him signed up through the ACA exchange within the week? 

Next step will be to negotiate the bills down.  My dad owns his house and vehicles outright, but I'm concerned the bills (even under a payment plan) will be huge.  What can I do to minimize the impact this will have to his credit?

**Outside the Box Ideas**

Since my dad had a stroke, does that open any possibility of me becoming his legal caretaker or something whereby he'd qualify to be covered under my family insurance?  I have very good health insurance through my employer in California.

Negotiating Hospital Bill - Are these charges unusual?

So this does not have to do with insurance, but does have to do with a hospital bill.  My father was hospitalized a few weeks ago for a stroke and he was uninsured at that time.  So far, the bill is $84,840.27.  Since he is "cash pay," the hospital has offered a 30% discount right off the bat, so this bill is $59,338.18.  I'm not sure if this 30% discount is only available if you pay off the whole bill at once.  I hope that is not the case.  I received an itemized copy of the bill, which I've posted here: [https://imgur.com/a/JGQIRMo](https://imgur.com/a/JGQIRMo)

From what I've read, I should be combing through this bill to dispute any charges that seem excessive or incorrect.  All I know is that he was in the hospital for four days and basically waiting around the whole time.  According to the nurse, he should have been in and out in two days, but the hospital was busy, so he was there for four.  Not sure if this helps from a negotiation standpoint.  

Do any of these charges look unusual or look like something that can be negotiated down?

Thanks for the help.  My dad is now insured.  Expensive lesson.

Does my Rental Car Insurance NOT Cover Hit and Run Incident Damage?

I was renting a car through Enterprise.  The car was hit very hard by a hit and run and driver and likely totaled the vehicle.  I have primary insurance that's transferable to the renter, which covers me under collision policy.  However, I also have secondary insurance through American Express, as I reserved and paid for the rental with my eligible American Express card.  While skimming through the Amex policy ([policy document here in Amex website](https://www.americanexpress.com/content/dam/amex/us/credit-cards/features-benefits/policies/NAC-Benefit-Guides/Benefit-Guide-1-1-20/CRLDI_Benefit_Guide_371-396_EDT_01.20_REV_10.20.pdf)), I noticed it doesn't say anything about hit and run drivers.  It DOES say this on page 5:

>What is Not Covered?  
>  
>10. personal liability, uninsured/underinsured motorists, personal injury protection, worker's compensation injuries, disability benefits of any kind, any coverage mandated by government or any other form of insurance coverage except as specifically described herein

I'm assuming the hit and run driver was either uninsured or underinsured, which is why they fled to begin with.  Either way, the driver got away.  Do insurance companies typically count hit and run drivers as "uninsured/underinsured"

Edit: I live in California and this is where the incident happened.

Make Big Purchase on CC without Impacting Credit Score

I'm in the process of buying a house and I'm towards the end of my 60-day mortgage shopping window.  I might need to run credit within the next 30 days to lock in an interest rate if I get under contract. 

I was in an auto accident and will be receiving a $7k check from my insurance to pay for the damage.  Body shop takes credit cards with no fee.  Can I post that $7k bill on a credit card and then immediately transfer $7k cash to my credit card account to cover the charge to get the points without Impacting Credit utilization component of my credit score?  I think my total credit card max is like $24,000 with all three of my credit cards combined.

Denied Life Insurance - Interested in Protecting Home after I die

I'm in a position where I unexpectedly cannot get life insurance.  I am 32 and have a pre-existing health condition (heart related) and have been denied from basically every carrier.  Admittedly, I was clueless about life insurance up until a few weeks ago, but I am where I am and I totally get why I look more risky on paper then someone else.  That said, I am the primary breadwinner for my family.  Mortgage debt is $595,000 (literally just bought a house) on a 30-yr mortgage.  Combined income is a about $200k.  HCOL area.  One step child (my wife's child who has a 50/50 custody arrangement with the father).  I'd like to protect my wife financially when I die in general, but more specifcally, the house, as she cannot make the mortgage payment on her own over a long period of time.

What are my options?  If I can't get an insurance product, what's the most tax efficient way for me to set aside savings that will transfer to her when I die?  I already max out my Roth IRA yearly (

current value $30,000) and I have a public pension.  I also have a Rollover IRA from my previous employer with about $80,000 in it.  My work offers life insurance standard at one-year's salary.  I tried increasing that voluntarily, but was denied.  I am currently researching how the death benefit of my pension plan works, but it will take some time.  Here's what my wife stands to get if I die:

**Employer Provided Death Benefit:** $130,000

**Roth IRA**: $30,000

**Rollover IRA**: $80,000

Will she receive a Social Security death benefit?  How can I calculate that?

Medical Review for Life Mortgage Protection Insurance

33 year old male, healthy, working a full-time office job.  I have a congenital heart condition that definitely makes me a risk for life insurance providers. My prognosis is good, but I'm definitely in a high risk group relative to the general population. Iâ€™m trying to find a policy that will cover me so that my wife will not lose our mortgaged home if I die. I am the primary breadwinner and weâ€™re in a high cost of living area.  Iâ€™ve tried to find typical life insurance through two different brokers and even tried on my own online with no luck. I now have a broker that says we should submit an application and just try to get through underwriting to get a mortgage-only life insurance policy. The policy will just cover the remainder of the mortgage balance if I pass away. Part of the application process will be a medical records review.

I currently receive basic life insurance through my work, which is one-years salary payable on death. Last year, I tried to add coverage onto that policy, but was denied. I had to fill out a form that required me to check the box for heart conditions and thatâ€™s why I think I was denied. I could not find out any more information from my workâ€™s HR department.

Question: is there any reason why I shouldnâ€™t go for the life insurance that just covers the mortgage balance and submit to a medical records review? I want to tread carefully, as I hear a review of medical records review could put a permanent mark on my record for insurers. I donâ€™t fully understand how it all works.

mysolo401k.net vs. Naber's solo401k.com: Recommendation for solo-401k platform?

I am currently looking at [mysolo401k.net](https://mysolo401k.net) and [solo401k.com](https://solo401k.com) to open a roth solo-401k so I can do mega backdoor Roth contributions. Does anyone have a preference of one platform over another? Naber's looks a bit cheaper year to year which is why I was planning to go with them unless there was a better reason to go with another provider?

Investing in Chick-fil-A stock

I know Chick-fil-A is a private company owned by their family. I'm just wondering with all the expansion will we ever see them go public? I really want a piece of the action. On one hand I'm sort of glad they don't go public because the minute you start answering to shareholders they start cutting corners to improve profits quarter over quarter which leads to s*** service which leads to more profits next quarter which leads to worst products and then the cycle continues until the flame burns out like most public companies where they are now just skeletons of their former heyday. On the other hand I would love to be an investor in such a well-run company with a great product.

Recommended vanguard mutual funds for a young investor

I've been in the workforce for about 10 years now. I'm 33 years old, I'm single, live alone, house is paid off after 5 years into the mortgage. My monthly disposable income after all expenses is approximately $2300. I currently have about $430,000 saved in my 401k and Roth IRA. Because I Max those accounts out every year I also opened a taxable brokerage account a while ago and I've been investing in the vanguard Total stock market index fund admiral shares, vanguard Total Bond market index fund admiral shares, s&p 500 index fund admiral shares. My asset allocation is approximately 95% stock mutual funds with the remaining in bonds.

My question is are there better mutual funds to be in that are still low cost but great return? I was watching some of Dave Ramsey's content last night and he mentioned four different classes of investments. It was kind of concerning because he was stating his mutual fund selections are based purely off the historical nature of the funds performance and if it beats the s&p 500. He also talked about how you need to have aggressive growth and income funds etc. my thinking is if I own a total stock market index fund wouldn't that cover both growth and income oriented stocks? Do I really need to be more diversified than this? I mean I understand and see there are other funds offered by vanguard that do have higher historical returns which seems like they would be worth the extra fee. Which vanguard funds are you all invested in? I really like the passive, cost efficient long-term perspective of index funds. I want to make sure that I'm watching my fun'ds up for the Long haul in a great investment.

Why are people duped on the American greed TV show?

I don't understand why so many people end up investing with an individual through a recommendation rather than just going and investing in low-cost mutual funds like index funds at vanguard? I noticed some of them are promised 20% returns with no down side in some of the episodes and guaranteed preservation of your principal. How is this still a thing in 2020?

Money is such an important part of our lives and we should all strive to manage our own money with recommendations and advice coming from the professionals. But they should not be doing it for us. That seems to be the number one theme that keeps reoccurring in every episode of the show. people want to turn over the most important asset in their life to someone else other than taking a little time to manage it themselves.

What does the journey look like to 25,000 per month in real estate investments?

I'm interested in getting into real estate and wanted to find out what the capital and effort involved would look like to reach $25,000 per month net after all expenses? they say real estate is not get rich quick but if you have a good base of cash to work with up front perhaps it can be?

Tax implications of working a W-2 job and a 1099 job

I currently have a W-2 job making about 140k per year and I'm considering adding a second job making roughly the same amount. I work remote and I have a lot of free time with my current job so I figured I'd add a second one to the mix. Logistics of meetings and other concerns aside, I'm wondering if it would be better for the second job to be another w2 job or a 1099 job when it comes to taxes?

I don't plan to take any of the benefits from the second job. If I did it would probably only be the 401K match to get the free money.

Back door Roth with possible pro rata issues

My MAGI is about $146,000 for 2020 so my income level is too high to make a Roth contribution. I was thinking about making a non deductible traditional IRA contribution and then converting it to a Roth. The problem is I already own a traditional IRA with about 240,000 in it. The articles I've read don't talk about this too much. 

So if I open a brand new fresh traditional IRA at vanguard with a $0 balance, make a non deductible contribution and convert it as quickly as possible to a Roth IRA, that wouldn't allow me to just make the contribution without having to worry about extra taxes? assuming no gains in the short time the money is in there. My other existing traditional IRA would come into effect somehow with taxes? Ideally I would like to make a non-deductible contribution for 2021 and 2020. I made a contribution in neither of those years

Rolling IRA back into a 401K to avoid pro rata rules?

My income is too high to make a contribution to a roth IRA so I wanted to make a backdoor contribution. However I currently have a traditional IRA balance and the pro rata rules would dictate that about 97% of my non-deductible $6K contribution to the IRA that gets moved to the roth IRA ends up being taxable. So to avoid this I was thinking I could rollover my IRA into my employer's 401K and then I would have a zero dollar balance and avoid the pro rata rules.

What would the timeline look like for this? Does the IRS consider it to be ok if I have $0 IRA balance across all IRA's at the time I make the contribution or is there a period of time I need to wait once the money is moved back to the 401k?

Buy a rental property now or save more and buy a bigger rental property later?

I'm planning to retire at around age 45. I am currently 33 years old and have about $900,000 saved. I found a great personal retirement calculator spreadsheet on one of these subreddits and even with extremely conservative numbers of 8% returns it estimates I'll retire at age 45 with around 4 million dollars assuming I continue to invest 70% of my $137,000 pay every year. That doesn't make much sense to me though. The market only doubles your money roughly every 10 years give or take. So I am a little skeptical of that.

Regardless I'm thinking rental property would be a good way to carry me further along without touching my nest egg.however every time I've looked at a multi-family property the commercial loan terms seem unfavorable or they are not leaving enough room for paying down the mortgage aggressively because the cash flow is so tight. plus I know right now is probably not the best time to buy property with the market being so hot.

This is more question of opportunity cost and I'm having a difficult time of deciding which approach is best. Should I save a boatload of money and continue investing as normal in the market and then maybe around age 42 I look at taking a chunk of that money and buying the rental property to sustain me going forward? Or do I continue down the path of trying to get a rental property today because leverage is a beautiful thing after all. Then by the time I hit 45 maybe most of it will be paid off. It would seem like the smart thing to do is invest in the market for now since cap rates on property are around 5% in my area. The market stand a great chance of doing considerably better than that. I invest primarily in growth and aggressive growth. I don't think I have anything really on the income side as much.

How Much Withholding do I Need?

I'm really not understanding how much to withhold based on the IRS directions. I have a W2 salary of $137K and a 1099 income of roughly $57,600 (it fluctuates and could be as high as $96,000). I've had the W2 job all year and the first 1099 payment was at the very end of March.

How much should I pay in quarterly taxes if at all? I was planning to just add the additional withholding to my employer's W4.

Opportunity cost of investing in real estate or investing

I've been a long time investor in the markets and I feel much more comfortable with them but a friend recently has gotten me interested in real estate. My interest really begins and ends with the rent payments. The thought of managing tenants does not sound exciting to me but he makes it sound like it's very little effort on his part despite doing rehabs on every wholesale deal he gets. Obviously they need some rehabbing because they're wholesale deals.

Anyways I have $100,000 sitting in an account and I'm feeling the itch to get it invested whether that's in real estate or the markets. How does everyone feel these days about one over the other?

Maximizing retirement account contributions with self-employment income

I have a W-2 job and I maximize my 401k contributions. I also have a traditional IRA which I use to roll over non-deductible contributions into my Roth IRA (backdoor roth). I currently have a 1099 job on the side and I'm starting to think it makes sense to open a SEP IRA or a solo 401k so that I can contribute even more. I'm thinking the solo 401K makes the most sense because I can use the Roth option to make another $19,500 contribution in addition to the 19,500 contribution I make at my employer's W-2 401k? I'm getting a little bit confused as to which accounts I can maximize assuming that I can maximize all of them.

Is it possible to have multiple LLCs and have multiple contribution limits for sep iras?

If I have one LLC and then I make employer contributions to it up to the 58,000 limit and then I have another LLC that I do different work under what I also get another $58,000 limit under that one or is it just $58,000 across all of your self-employed retirement accounts? I assume this is irrespective of W-2 plans because I do have a 401k and Roth IRA that I contribute to and maximize every year as well.

1099 versus W-2 pay

I currently have a W2 job and I also have an LLC through which I do 1099 work. I'm still unclear of which one is the better choice long-term. I plan to continue doing both of them but from an income perspective it seems like the 1099 can pay more overall because it's not concerned with benefits and other Fringe stuff. You also have the benefit of making employer contributions to yourself in a Solo 401K that are far greater than the employee contribution limits.

So I guess my question is does it make sense with all of the extra tax you pay as a 1099 contractor? Is it more profitable long-term? The other aspect beyond profitability that I'm considering is which one is easier. 1099 jobs feel like they have more hour watching than a W-2 which just kind of hires you and throws you into a massive pool of employees and the work is way less intense it feels like. So from a easy big and bloated bureaucratic company perspective where you don't have to do a lot of work it sounds like W-2 is a better approach?

Solo 401K Rules for Employer Contributions

I have a W2 job and I plan to fully fund my 401K for 2021 ($19,500) and my employer matches money as well up to a certain amount. If I have a two LLCs, can each of them open a solo 401K and make up to $58K in employer only contributions or is the $58K limit across all employers (my LLCs and my W2).

I guess I'm thinking of it similar to an employee contribution. The max for employee is $19,500 across all jobs and LLCs and $58K for all employer contributions?

Just trying to understand where the limits are for contributions across these different accounts.

Multifamily syndication performance versus index funds?

I've been looking at investing some of my money into a multi-family syndication like Praxis Capital but I question how to properly evaluate their historical performance against the performance of the s&p 500 or total stock market index fund? It seems like some of their historical investments have been as high as 19% which would obviously put them at a much better advantage than an index fund. Just curious on what people's thoughts are as far as performance is concerned and if they prefer multifamily syndications for their immediate cash flow and tax efficiency over investing in index funds?

For context I do mostly invest in index funds today.

Should I just pay the TurboTax estimated payment vouchers to cover taxes for next year?

I have a W-2 job and several 1099 jobs with income that varies wildly. TurboTax gave me some nifty payment vouchers that state $1076 is what I should pay per quarter. So my understanding is that is minimum amount I should be this year for 2022 per quarter to avoid a penalty regardless if my income will be higher?

Should I use the prepayment vouchers of $1076 as a floor/minimum for quarterly payments but actually target something closer to 35% of the 1099 income I bring in for the quarter since I expect my income to be north of $215,950? [**This article**](https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/how-to-pay-quarterly-taxes) provided a simplified method stating: withhold 35% for incomes over $215,950 for single filers.

Should I be looking into refinancing my home right now?

Anyway, I plan to rent out my home to my sister in the next year or so as Iâ€™m moving in with my partner so is it worth it to refi?

$165,000 condo at 5.5%

I asked, but didn't get a clear answer as to if/when.  


Edit: Not talking about a quote from Zillow, but from a local bank or something.

I took a hit to my credit score and Credit Karma (I know) says I had a deferred payment, even though Iâ€™ve never missed anything. Thoughts?

How should be sibling pay rent from me?

I bought a condo 2 years ago. I'm moving in with my partner in a few months to his house, and my sister wanted to move into my place. I LOVE my condo so I'm glad I don't have to sell it yet and that my sister can rent it from me for a year or so.

The cost of the mortgage and utilities and HOA:

1. Mortgage: $1050
2. HOA: $330
3. Utilities: $150

Of course my sister would pay for the utilities on her own so no issues there, I'll move everything onto her name. For the HOA, it'll still be under my name so either I can link it to her bank account or she can Venmo me. In terms of the mortgage, it's through US Bank and actually attached to my personal bank account as well. I thought about just having her send me the money through Venmo, but I'm wondering if there'll be any issues seeing all this "income" each month through Venmo. I will note I'm still going to be paying $200 of my place so that can go into the mortgage or HOA and what not. Just want to do this the best way.

Bought a car two weeks ago, looking to get a new house. Should I apply now re: credit scores/hits?

I really couldn't find a straightforward answer so thought I'd come here. I just bought a new vehicle from the dealership financed through them. My credit pull was two weeks ago today. My partner and I are looking into buying a new house as well. We met with an advisor and they recommended I apply with my information due to having better credit and what not.

Should I be applying, like now? Someone mentioned I should because it may not be an additional hard inquiry, but I couldn't find clear info on timeline. Also not sure if it matters because my credit pull two weeks ago was for a car and this would be for a house.

How much of my salary should go to my 401K?

My company started matching my 401K up to 4.5% if I go over 6%. The last year I just had 6% but should I do more? My salary is around $87,000K. I do have student loan debt, car debt and a new home that i pay with my partner, but not sure what to do.

Is it worth shifting to a High-Yield Savings Account right now?

I have a smaller emergency fund but itâ€™s next to my checking, my mortgage and one credit card I have within US bank. The % is awful but itâ€™s nice that itâ€™s connected.

Is it worth looking into Ally for example right now? Iâ€™ve been watching rates overall and they keep dropping quite a bit overall so not sure if itâ€™s worth me shifting and adding the hassle of a new platform.

Edit: I also have two chase cards and two AmEx.

I had a dental bill roll in after the New Year, any negatives to using my 2021 FSA money?

I put a couple hundred dollars in my FSA last year and this year. I had two small dental thing in November and early December. I paid my first bill in December with my remaining FSA which was about $150. I just got the bill for the December appointment. Any negatives to using the FSA on it right away or just paying with my credit card? Typically I wouldn't have planned on using it this soon.

First time having my own insurance so not sure if there are benefits or negatives.

Thank you!

Quick tax question about refunds and owing

I've had one day job and a side hustle for the past couple years and I've gotten decent tax returns over the past couple years. 

In 2020, my sister moved into my condo and started paying me rent (in August so 5 months). I moved out as an FYI so she pays a significant amount. That said, I was doing my taxes this year and saw that I actually will be owing Federal and State (less than $100 total so no big deal), but does that make sense as to why?

It's because I'm getting income for the rental from my sister, even though the day job and side hustle haven't changed much?

Any easy ways to change my billing address?

I recently moved (thankfully my family still lives at the old place so I have had my billing address there) but I want to change everything over as they're moving out soon.

Is there an easy way to know what things I need to change or is it literally just thinking of anything I can?

Easy ones to start of course are banks/credit cards, but what about all those shopping sites, other things like travel/hotel stuff. Any advice? It sounds so daunting..

Should I be enrolling in my companyâ€™s ESPP?

I work at a large company and they offer enrolling in ESPP twice a year. I got an email that this week is the time. I can put anywhere from 1-10% in this and at the end of the period (EOY) I can purchase my companyâ€™s stock at 10% off.

I have an emergency savings and a solid 401K but thatâ€™s about it.

28 years old. Any recommendations and if yes, how much?

Should I be doing ESPP and then selling them right away?

I work at a large company (Fortune 10 company) and have not taken advantage of ESPP in the past. My company recently changed how it works and now provided the following:

* Contributions are automatically deducted from your paycheck (after taxes) throughout the six-month purchase period. 
* At the end of the purchase period, your contributions are used to purchase company stock at a 10% discount.

It used to be the lower price during the 6 month period (which seems to be the norm), but looks like it's just a 10% discount at the end. 

Should I be taking advantage of this? How much should I put in (I can anywhere from 1%-10% of my salary)? And then should I sell or hold?

The stock itself peaked in May and dropped a little bit, but has been steadily increasing again. In general it's been insane growth. Since I started, the stock cost doubled.. should have probably done ESPP sooner. Anyway, thoughts?

Looking for help planning out my retirement accounts and employee ESPP.

I had a post a bit ago about my company's ESPP that is live right now for enrollment until the end of the month that gives us a 10% discount on our company stock which seems to be something I should do, but Fidelity in itself is really confusing to me and I did ESPP before, had a 401K from an old role moved over to a Rollover IRA and so on. Here is the lay of the land and I'm hoping someone could help guide me on what to do with my money to set me up. I'm in my mid-twenties making $110,000 if that's helpful context.

* 401K right now is 6% with an employee match: $38K
* I did ESPP once a few years ago and apparently didn't sell the stocks right away so I have an Individual account with $600 in my company stock.
* I have a Rollover IRA of about $300 from an old 401K contribution from an old job that didn't last long.
* I do not have a Roth or Traditional IRA (not the most educated on it).
* My savings account is going to be wiped out pretty much in a month or two as well after a home repair, unfortunately. If that plays into this at all.

Let me know if there's more information I can provide. I'm trying to decide how much money to put towards the ESPP (1% - 10%) before the end of the month enrollment ends. I'm also trying to decide what I'm supposed to do with the Rollover money that has been sitting there, not invested in anything for quite some time.

A message to retired folks who are 100% stocks

Jerry retired on January 1st, 2000 with One Million Dollars in his 401K and used the 4% rule so his first annual withdrawal was $40,000.  Each year he adjusted his annual withdrawal up by the rate of inflation. On December 31, 2008, he only had  $403,770 left and he was now taking out 12% of his balance due to annual inflation increases based on the 4% rule.

His friend Chris decided to be more conservative and went 50% a total bond and 50% total stock. On December 31, 2008, he had $910,454 left and was taking out 5.49% of his portfolio out in withdrawals.

The stock market would keep dropping a few more months and as far as anyone knew, it could go down even further.

Jerry's greed going with a 100% stock portfolio caused him many nights of fear and sleepless nights. By 2009 his health was so bad by the stress he had a massive heart attack. He lived but is still in bad health. Chris is still doing well today with a portfolio worth $1.4 million.

If you withdraw and spend the dividend payment of an investment that crashed- you lost money!

The Internet is full of naive statements about how if you live on the dividend payments you are protected from market crashes.

Here are two examples to review for your discussion and analysis:

Doug owns a growth stock mutual fund that does not pay any dividends that he bought at $50.00 a share.  We enter a recession and his growth mutual fund has crashed 50% and now is valued at $25.00 a share. Doug is retired and needs to pay his bills and takes 4% out of his investment portfolio every year. He sells 4% of his mutual fund that dropped 50% and is now selling at $25.00 a share.  After his withdrawal, he has lost 54% of his investment portfolio.

Mark owns a high yield stock mutual fund that also dropped 50% during the bear market. His high yield mutual fund has a 4% yield. The dividend is paid once a year every December. Mark pays his retirement bills with the 4% annual distribution from the dividend of his mutual fund.  Mark feels like a genius because he lives on dividends and does not touch the principal.  After spending the 4% dividend he still has the same number of shares he had before. I told him he is no better off than Doug because on the ex-dividend day the value of his stock dropped an equal amount of the dividend.  So he now his 4% less value in his mutual fund portfolio, just like Doug.  Mark tell me I am wrong.   We have to agree to disagree.

Are you with Doug or Mark on this question?

If my stock portfolio is down from its all-time high I feel like I lost money!

Let me tell all of you a story that relates to the gambling aspect of the stock market: (And the topic of paper gains and loses.)

I am visiting Las Vegas and playing Blackjack.  Even though there is a casino advantage of 1-3% I am doing great.  After three days and evenings at the Blackjack table, I am up about 30% of my original bankroll. Instead of cashing in my chips every day I brought them up to my hotel room and admired them and counted them again and again. I dreamed about what I could do with my winnings.

On the 4th day, my luck at the Blackjack table took a turn for the worse and I started to lose money.  I stopped gambling and cashed in my chips.  After careful analysis, I determined I was up about 5% from my original investment.  So I left Las Vegas with more money than I started with.  But I felt like a loser because I had been up 30% before.  I had admired the chips and counted them and had plans for spending my windfall.  

The same thing happened to me in my stock market investments.  I was once up about 30% but held on got greedy and hoped to make even more money.  But then the stock market dropped about 25% and I cashed out with a five percent gain. But again I felt like a loser because I could have cashed out of my stocks with a 30% gain.

In both cases, I felt like a loser.  Can you relate?

Math issue related to investing Social Security Checks

Jerry retired at age 62 but does not need his Social Security checks.  (He has a nice pension and investments.)   But he still decides to start collecting benefits starting at age 62 and invests the money.  in a 60-40 mutual fund. His first Social Security check is about $1500 a month which increases each year by the rate of inflation (1-3% a year)

On his 70th Birthday, he has about $220K in his investment account from deposits and capital gains from his invested Social Security Checks.

His twin brother Ben also decided to retire at age 62 but won't collect SS until he is 70. Ben was proud to say his SS checks will be almost twice the amount of his twin brother Jerry because he waited to 70 to collect. (Even though they had about the same lifetime income.)

Jerry- who collected SS at age 62-  decided to challenge Ben to a contest. Starting at age 70 he would withdraw from his $220K nest egg the difference between their Social Security checks so they both were given the same amount of money per month. AGAIN, Jerry would withdraw about $1500 a month out of his $220K nest egg he got from investing his smaller SS checks for 8 years so he would have the same income as Ben. (Social Security check + $1500 a month will match Ben's larger SS payment.)  The ending date of the contest is age 90.

Jerry insists because he started the contest with $220K, he can live into his 90s and still come out ahead because he will still be earning investment returns from his initial nest egg. Vs Ben has no nest egg at age 70  just a larger SS check. Who will win the contest based on typical stock market returns for a 60-40 fund?

People say: "Past performance is not indicative of future results" (Is this really true?)

I am always hearing this statement:  ***Past performance is not indicative of future results.***

There is some truth to it but I believe the statement at face value is false.  I believe that historically there are certain commonalities to the stock and bond markets that time and time again are true.  In other words, history repeats itself over and over so we can be 90% sure in the future it will keep happening:

**Here are some examples of investing rules of thumb that have been true historically and with 90% certainty will continue to be true:**

Short Term Bond funds are less volatile than Long Term Bond Funds

A Bear Market in short term and intermediate bond funds is not as harsh as a bear market in stocks

Growth Small Company stocks are more volatile than large blue chips

Consumer Staple Stocks are less volatile than NASDAQ Technology Stocks in a bear market

If Stocks crash in a bear market they go back up within a few years (Every bear market has had a recovery.)

If the economy continues to grow the stock market long term trend will be up.

Stocks with very high dividend yields are more likely to be volatile than a stock with a smaller dividend yield

**What are other rules of the stock and bond markets that show that past performance can be a strong indicator of future investment results?**

&#x200B;

Interesting tidbits about the last four decades of stock market returns

Everyone is talking about how great the stock market has been since 2010.  But if someone would have put an inflation-adjusted $1000 a year into a total stock market fund and reinvested the dividends the decade of 2010-2019 has only been average.  In fact, the third-best of the last four decades.  (I used this approach because most investors are adding money to their accounts on a regular basis via a 401K or 403B)  Each ten year period is in isolation to each other.

**$1 to start and then $1000 a year investment (adjusted up for inflation), dividends reinvested- would be worth:**

1980-1989= $28,751

1990-1999= $32,014

2000-2009= $12,626

2010-2019= $20,335

Your thoughts?

In a Bear Market, it is much better to break your investments in separate total stock and total bond funds than use balanced mutual funds in retirement

I want to show you the math behind the advantages of having separate total stock and total bond funds vs using balanced mutual funds.

Jim retired on October 1st, 2007 and had 2 Million Dollars in his 401K retirement account and is using the 4% rule and is planning on withdrawing a starting figure of $6666 a month which will be adjusted for inflation. He has two accounts 60% of his money is in a total stock market fund and 40% in a total bond market fund. Just when he retires the stock market starts to crash so he pulls his $6666 a month withdrawal out of his bond fund so he does not sell his stocks when they are down. On March 1, 2009, just before the stock market hits bottom he has $955,736 in his total Bond Fund and $519,680 in his total stock market fund. ($1,475,416 combined) Starting in March 2009 he took his monthly withdrawals equally from both funds. On February 2020 he has $2,598,449 left.

Peter also retired on October 2007 and had $2 Million in retirement and put it all in a 60-40 Mutual Fund. On March 1st he had $1,164,377 in his Balanced 60-40 Mutual Fund (FBALX) He took an inflation-adjusted starting amount of $6666.00 a month out of that fund from October 2007 to February 2020. So, in the end, on February 2020 he had $2,489,195 left.

Why the difference? Because Peter used a balanced mutual fund that was selling stocks during the Great Recession (due to the investment having 60% in stocks). While Jim only withdrew from his bond funds during the 2007-2009 stock market crash.

Check my figures on this great website:

[https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/backtest-portfolio#analysisResults](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/backtest-portfolio#analysisResults)

Funny TurboTax bug (involving self-employment income on Form 8959)

I've been working on my 2022 tax return (largely to decide if I need to make a Q4 estimated tax payment or if I already paid enough in the first three quarters), and I discovered a funny bug in TurboTax.  I prepared my return in both FreeTaxUSA and TurboTax, and FreeTaxUSA showed a refund that was hundreds of dollars larger.  After going through the forms, I found the difference on line 8 of Form 8959 (Additional Medicare Tax, where household income over a certain threshold is taxed an extra 0.9%).  The value on Form 8959 line 8 comes from Schedule SE line 6, and FreeTaxUSA brought it over just fine, but TurboTax doubled it, resulting in hundreds of dollars more in tax.

As I messed around trying to fix the problem, I eventually figured out that TurboTax has two versions of Schedule SE, which show up as "Sch SE-T" and "Sch SE-S."  I also figured out that TurboTax uses Sch SE-T for self-employment income that's attributed to the first-named person on a joint return and Sch SE-S for self-employment income attributed to the second-named person (I suspect the "T" stands for "taxpayer" and the "S" stands for "spouse").  In any event, when I change my return so the person with the self-employment income is named first (and TurboTax uses Sch SE-T), the error on Form 8959 goes away.  When I change it back, so the person with the self-employment income is named second (and TurboTax uses Sch SE-S), the error reappears.

What does tax software do with information (like employer name and ID # from your W-2) that doesn't actually go on your tax return?

When using tax software (I'm using FreeTaxUSA, but I think this is true in general), they ask for things like your employer's name and employer's federal ID number (from your W-2) that don't actually show up on a finished tax return.  Are they transmitting this extra information to the IRS "behind the scenes"?

I keep wondering, though, don't bonds reduce volatility at the expense of returns?  Assuming that's right, what if you simply didn't care about volatility (you have nerves of steel or whatever) and had a flexible enough time-horizon that you could wait out any downturn or otherwise minimize sale of stocks that are down?  Bottom-line: Would an all-stock portfolio outperform a portfolio with bonds across the long term?

Even if we imagine a worst-case scenario in which a major downturn coincides with your retirement, wouldn't decades of maxed-out growth help your overall position (again, assuming that's what you'd get by being all in stocks)?  Sure, your portfolio would be down -- maybe way down -- but it'd be down from a higher high, right?  Also, it's not like you're going to liquidate your entire portfolio the day you retire -- you'd only sell enough for that week or month or whatever, so while it sucks to sell low, there'd be plenty other times when you'd get to sell at record highs (assuming a long enough retirement), and wouldn't continuing to max out growth be beneficial during retirement, as well?

I assume people have run simulations on this and concluded that we're better off with bonds (and an increasing amount of bonds as we approach retirement), but it's just never made sense to me.

How does this work on the employer side, though?  Given a single job, when an employee reaches the social security maximum, both the employee AND the employer stop paying their respective 6.2%, right? To make things simple, let's suppose someone earns exactly the social security maximum ($147k for 2022) in W-2 income and another $147k in self-employment/1099 income.  The employee only has to pay social security tax on $147k, but what about the employer side?  Can the entire employer responsibility be put on the W-2 employer and the self-employment/1099 income be taken free of social security tax (thus netting the self-employed individual an additional 6.2%)? Negotiating on Salary/Sign On with Future Boss Who is also a Friend

Title says it all, but for more context:

At my current job I worked for someone for \~3 years, then reported through their chain for a few years after we both got some promotions. Fantastic working relationship the entire time.

During this time we also became good friends. (Kids hung out, came to our wedding, we go out to dinner with them, whatever).

6 months ago they left for a new company, said they'd come calling if they had something that was right for me. They called.

Now I'm in the position of considering their offer against my current company.

If I was going to any other company, with any other person, I'd make a counter offer for the new company to cover the equity that I'm losing in my current company and I'd consider asking for them to cover my lost bonus. At my level, this isn't an uncommon practice, but not in every case. (Maybe 15 - 35% of the time?).

Are there any special watch outs I should be thinking about when presenting a counter offer that includes some buy out given the closer personal ties? Or am I just over thinking it and I should treat it like any other job offer?

My initial instinct is that I'm over thinking it and I should just do my research for what's acceptable, and or not outrageous and make an offer in line with general expectations / reasonability. If they counter and say no, then I can make a call then. But if they are really the friend and professional advocate that I think they are, then they won't be offended by a well reasoned counter.

Picking Insurance For Next Year

I'm having a bit of a tough time picking what insurance we should get for next year. Some context: My wife will almost certainly max out any limit that she has. She regularly goes to Therapy, PT, and for the last few years she's unfortunately been in and our of the hospital for various things, all of which are out of her control. There's some injections/back issues that are in play for next year too. The rest of the family (me and the kid) are generally very healthy, and don't really go to the doctor that much, mostly just generic preventative type stuff. Obv could change, but that's been the history.

My options are:  
Traditional: $441/month (fam), $1k deductible (personal), $3k deductible (fam), 20% co-insurance for most services, $4k max OOP (personal), $12k max OOP (fam), co-pays are flat fees depending on the service

HDP: $310/month (fam), $2k deductible (personal), $4k deductible (fam), 20% co-insurance for more services, $6k max OOP (personal), $9.1k max OOP (fam), co-pays are 20% for all services, company kicks in $1,200 as a side benefit to the HPHD

The way that I'm thinking about this:

The wife will max out the OOP most likely regardless of the limit. The fam will likely not, but could obv. If the wife maxes her OOP, on the trad we're paying \~9k (440\*12+4000) + whatever the rest of the fam needs. On the HDHP we're paying \~9.7k ($310\*12+6000), less the $1.2k that work kicks in. Also less the tax benefit of the HSA which will max out (or approx $7k \* 25%) so -1.7k in taxes.

Cost Of Racism: U.S. Economy Lost $16 Trillion Because Of Discrimination, Bank Says

[https://www.npr.org/sections/live-updates-protests-for-racial-justice/2020/09/23/916022472/cost-of-racism-u-s-economy-lost-16-trillion-because-of-discrimination-bank-says](https://www.npr.org/sections/live-updates-protests-for-racial-justice/2020/09/23/916022472/cost-of-racism-u-s-economy-lost-16-trillion-because-of-discrimination-bank-says)

 

Nationwide protests have cast a spotlight on racism and inequality in the United States. Now a major bank has put a price tag on how much the economy has lost as a result of discrimination against African Americans: $16 trillion.

Since 2000, U.S. gross domestic product lost that much as a result of discriminatory practices in a range of areas, including in education and access to business loans, according to [a new study](https://ir.citi.com/NvIUklHPilz14Hwd3oxqZBLMn1_XPqo5FrxsZD0x6hhil84ZxaxEuJUWmak51UHvYk75VKeHCMI%3D) by Citigroup. It's not an insignificant number: By comparison, [U.S. GDP](https://www.bea.gov/news/2020/gross-domestic-product-2nd-quarter-2020-second-estimate-corporate-profits-2nd-quarter) totaled $19.5 trillion last year.

And not acting to reverse discriminatory practices will continue to exact a cost. Citigroup estimates the economy would see a $5 trillion boost over the next five years if the U.S. were to tackle key areas of discrimination against African Americans.

"We believe we have a responsibility to address current events and to frame them with an economic lens in order to highlight the real costs of longstanding discrimination against minority groups, especially against Black people and particularly in the U.S.," wrote Raymond J. McGuire, a vice chairman at the bank and the chairman of its banking, capital markets and advisory team.

Wall Street itself has also faced accusations for years of discriminatory practices against African Americans, such as limiting approval for mortgages or not providing enough banking options in minority neighborhoods, which are among the damaging actions identified by Citigroup researchers.

Specifically, the study came up with $16 trillion in lost GDP by noting four key racial gaps between African Americans and whites:

* $13 trillion lost in potential business revenue because of discriminatory lending to African American entrepreneurs, with an estimated 6.1 million jobs not generated as a result
* $2.7 trillion in income lost because of disparities in wages suffered by African Americans
* $218 billion lost over the past two decades because of discrimination in providing housing credit
* And $90 billion to $113 billion in lifetime income lost from discrimination in accessing higher education

As a result, Citigroup urges a slew of actions to reverse discriminatory practices and boost GDP over the next five years, including addressing the wage gap suffered by African Americans and promoting diversity at the top within banks and companies.

Citigroup's recommendations aren't new: Various studies have shown similar findings, and experts have called for similar action for years, though so far progress has been slow.

Should you budget to die with money?

Pretty much what the title says and I guess this is more philosophical than a financial question but when we do eventually retire and itch closer and closer to death (think being around 70-80 something), should we keep money in our investments and the bank still at that point? I mean we retire because working becomes more annoying than the money is worth, otherwise we'd keep working all our lives. So my question is at what point in your life is the money still worthwhile to you and at what point does that turn and it's value depreciates in your mind. Now, I understand hoarding some in your old age if you have a family and needs to be tended to after death but I don't have any kids and the only person I plan on having to be cared for after my death would be pets (whom I would leave to my younger brother). Henceforth, wouldn't it make sense to at some point just cash out your remaining investments and have some fun with them? I know of course, this might sound dumb because you don't know when you'll actually die but assuming you keep easily enough to keep your housing, food, and medical bills in order for the rest of your life, then wouldn't throwing out the last remaining bits on people and experiences you enjoy make sense? I wouldn't necessarily spend it on materialistic items seeing as those will simply be gone when you die but the rest could leave a lasting impact or even help others. I just keep thinking about this because in Sweden, they do "death cleaning" when they're approaching their elderly age in which they throw away or give away materialistic items so their inheritors don't have to go through it all and determine what to do with it all. So, shouldn't or couldn't the same be applied to money? You only leave what your inheritors could possibly need and not much more, giving away or spending the rest in a manner you see fitting of the money? I don't truly know the answer, interested to hear your thoughts.

How to choose a financial advisor/planner.

If you want to do it yourself thatâ€™s fine. If youâ€™d prefer to hire a professional these are the 3 questions to ask. 

1) Are you a CFP? 

CFPs are the cream of the crop in the industry. They go through more extensive education and training and have experience requirements that donâ€™t exist for your average advisor. 

2) Do you charge fees or commissions?

You want to eliminate the conflicts of interest between you and your planner as best as possible. Commissions for trades are the worst compensation structure because they are getting paid regardless of the advice they give. Flat monthly fees are best because the advisor is now being compensated for the advice they give and not just the investments. Fee based and and Fee for assets model are the most common and fine as long as the advisor is worth the advice they are giving. Many of the best planners charge a fee for assets under management because itâ€™s the most lucrative business model and they have no trouble keeping and acquiring happy clients. 

3) What if I wanted to buy a stock?

You donâ€™t want an old school stock picking broker who hasnâ€™t kept up with the times. The evidence is clear that index funds are better than most mutual funds and picking stocks. The advisor should reply with some form of, â€œyou can do whatever youâ€™d like with your money, but if we are going to work together I do whatâ€™s been proven to maximize your chances of success in the long term, and that means I donâ€™t pick stocks and I donâ€™t try and time the marketsâ€. This may seem harsh but if they are willing to let you do it then they have one foot in the old school and a good sign theyâ€™re not truly objective. 

* if you find yourself in some niche like government employee, doctor, dentist, retiree, employee stock options, and can find yourself a specialist who only works with these people and wonâ€™t take on others, this is ideal. Specialists are more valuable in finance for the same reason you want someone who does hips all day to replace yours as opposed to a general orthopedist. 


Good luck.

Is my house hacking strategy good?

I hopefully will be house hacking starting in 2023. Please analyze my strategy and let me know if you see any flaws or risks.

**Financials**

*All the calculations are based on a $2,000 mortgage.*

Income:

Gross: $67,800 yearly $5,688 monthly $2,844 bi-weekly

Net: $52,338 yearly $4,362 monthly $2,180 bi-weekly

Projected rental income (found tenant, ready to sign lease): $10,800 yearly $900 monthly

Current debt-to-income ratio (w/ mortgage included): 41%

Current debt-to-income ratio (w/ mortgage & rental income included): 36%

Emergency fund (cash reserves only, not including payment for closing costs & down payment): \~$12,000

% of net income spent on housing: 46

% of gross spent on housing: 35

% of net spent on housingÂ (w/ rental income): 40

% of gross spent on housingÂ (w/rental income): 31

**Rules of Thumb**

*No more than 30% of your gross monthly income should be spent on housing:*

A $2,000 mortgage puts me at 35%, but with the rental income itâ€™s 31%.

*Your mortgage payment shouldn't put you more than 36% DTI:*

A $2,000 mortgage puts me at 41% DTI, but with rental income itâ€™s 36%.

*The 4x rule (if you spend less than 20% of your current take-home income on debt):*

I currently spend less than 5% of my income on existing debts, so the 4x rule gives me a purchase price of \~$270,000 with no HOA dues. This is currently the price target Iâ€™m aiming for. So although these calculations are based on a $2,000 mortgage from a \~$300,000 purchase price, it will more likely be a $1,800-$1,900 mortgage.

*Emergency fund for household expenses to last at least 6 months:*

Stashing away $2,500 for 6 months puts me at $15,000, but by the time I officially close and have to start paying the loan I should be around there.

**Factors to consider:**

* My girlfriend will live with me, and her income was left out of the loan approval process purposefully to ensure we do not overextend ourselves. My current thoughts are that weâ€™ll just split the mortgage from whatâ€™s left over from the other tenant. Weâ€™ll be paying around $550 each with the current calculations.
* I would need to lose my job and BOTH of my roommates in order for me to be truly swamped. In this case, I could sell my \~$20,000 car and live off my current cash reserves to give me time to find another job or sell the house.
* I shouldn't rely on this but my quoted \~5% interest rate leaves room for improvement, so I could refinance down the line and save money.
* The tenant is only signing a lease for a year, so the rental income is not guaranteed for the life of the loan but hopefully my income will increase in 2 or 3 years to a point where I can cover their portion eventually or find another tenant. 

Are there any flaws in this way of thinking? Any other rules of thumb I should use?Â 

Thanks for all your help in navigating this!

Shady debt collection happening from medical care. How do I proceed?

I was in a rehab facility January and February last year after surgery.  I would say every other person in the facility was medicaid/medicare.  More on that in a second.

Thanksgiving week I received a bill that the facility hand wrote my forward to address on from a pharmacy out of state.  It was literally an invoice with my name on it, a due date back in August, and a bottom line amount due for a few hundred dollars.  Not a single indication of what the bill was for, when, etc.  I called the 800 number and they told me they would reprint the bill and send it to me.  I gave them my correct address.  The week after Christmas, I got another hand written forward of the exact same bill.  No changes, no updates, except the bill now said 'past due'.

The Monday after New Years, I received another letter, to the correct address from a collection agency saying I had a bill that was being collected on because I failed to pay it in August.  The only associated number was the same one I called before.  They tell you to press '6', then '1', etc, and you get a prompt that indicates you want to pay a on a collection notice.  Since it's the same number, and they have a menu prompt, this can't be an uncommon thing for them.

I got through to a representative, and explained they had been sending bills to the wrong place, I wasn't getting those bills, and when I did, there is no information in the bill as to what it was for.  The rep said they saw I had called to get a reprint, but that I refused to pay the bill.  I asked them if they could send me the actual invoice that i was supposedly missing, and they told me it looked like it was for 2 bills, one back in December of '21 for a partial Medicare copay.  I explained to them I am not on medicare (I still work and have private insurance), and I wasn't in the facility in December.

I asked them to send me an updated invoice to my email, that I think they have some mistakes on the bill, and to ask the collection agency to back down.  I also asked for a reference number for the call so when I called back i would have a case already opened.  She said I just needed to use my 'account id'.

It's been over a week, and I still haven't heard back from them.  What steps do I take next?  I feel I've done my best to figure this out.  It already seems a little shady, so I am not going to keep investing time into digging into this.  At what point will they start putting liens against me or ruining my credit?

TL;DR: Shifty looking medical bill was sent to the wrong address.  Several months later they have turned it over to a collection agency, but have so far failed to give me even the basics of what the original bill was for.  Now what?

The idea is to pay it off in the 2.3 years, any leftover money save up for a down payment for a new house (try to get about 100k, so we are halfway there with 50k savings), and then because of that aggressive strategy, just barely fund our roths (6K each). If we aren't able to save another 50K, after we pay off the condo, we will aggressively save for another year or two since we will own the condo and no mortgage payments. 

The grand idea... is rent out the condo (for 1.5-2k a month) and then use that to pay most of the monthly mortgage on a large house (20-30 year mortgage). Thus, since that is paying off most of the mortgage, our salaries will feel much larger than they are (used for investments, savings, set). 

The downside of this plan, is that we are neglecting our retirement accounts a bit for the next few years, as we might have to dip into savings/the down payment fund to get that 6k a year each. Basic Investing Advice to get you started.

I wrote this out for a friend, thought it might be helpful to share here too. The goal is to provide some context for beginners and show how to get started. Iâ€™m open to questions from anyone trying to learn, or critiques from the veterans.

First off the rule of thumb is to only have your emergency fund and expected upcoming expenses in cash, everything else should be invested. Think about how much cash you need, and in the meantime you can start small by investing a little bit each month and increasing your contributions as you get more comfortable. For how you should be investing, Iâ€™m going to recommend putting everything into a Total Stock Market Index Fund.
 
A Total Market Index Fund tracks the performance of the entire US stock market. The way it works is it has almost 3,700 different stocks in it, each weighted based on their total value in the stock market. For example Apple is the biggest company in the US by market value, worth 6.5% of the entire stock market. Microsoft is the next biggest at 5%. So if you have $100,000 invested in a Total Market Index Fund, itâ€™s like you actually have $6,500 invested in Apple, $5,000 in Microsoft, and so on based on each of the 3,700 stocks weighted values.
 
The S&P 500 is another popular index fund. It is comprised of the 500 biggest companies in the US and makes up over 2/3 of the total stock market, so it has a lot of overlap with the Total Stock Market Index Fund, but it has a little less exposure since it excludes the smaller companies. Historically the performances of these two indexes have been nearly identical.
 
The S&P 500 and Total Stock Market have had over 13% annual growth over the last 10 years, so in that timeframe $100,000 invested wouldâ€™ve grown to ~$370,000, which is a great example of how powerful investing is over sitting on cash, but itâ€™s also important to note that past performance does not guarantee future performance. These last 10 years have had particularly strong growth, and Iâ€™d be surprised if it keeps that pace.
 
The Total Stock Market fund and S&P 500 fund are both synonymous with â€œthe Market,â€ and are two examples of low-cost, passively invested index funds. Index funds seek market average returns, but there are thousands of actively managed mutual funds to choose from which are more expensive and exist on the belief that theyâ€™ll â€œbeat the Market.â€ Some do, but in reality most end up underperforming, which is why Iâ€™m recommending a cheap and easy index fund.
 
You can find these funds at any of the big investment firms: choose from either Fidelity, Vanguard, or Charles Schwab. To use Fidelityâ€™s Total Stock Market Index Fund, FSKAX, thereâ€™s no minimum investment, and the fee is only 0.015%, so every $1,000 you have invested will cost you 15 cents each year. Good practice for investing is to consistently contribute every month, as much as you can afford. You can do things like set up direct deposit to have a portion of your paycheck go straight to your investments, or automatically transfer some amount from your bank like $500 every month, or just contribute each month based on how much you have available. They have good customer service that will help you get setup.  
 
Note on the power of compounding interest: Historically the market has averaged 10% annual returns. At that rate of growth, if you were to invest $1,000/mo for 40 years, you would end up with over 5 million dollars, having contributed a total of $480,000. $500/mo would get you over 2.5 million dollars from $240,000 in total contributions.

Afterthought: Investing is much easier than most think, you just need to find the right fund(s) and contribute monthly, can even set that up automatically. It does get slightly more complex as you get older and as you accumulate more wealth. Once you cross a certain threshold of wealth, and Iâ€™m talking $200,000+ invested, itâ€™d be a good idea to get more diversified. And as you get closer to retirement, youâ€™ll want to invest more conservatively. But both of those are just a matter of adding a couple more funds to your portfolio and choosing how much you want in each one.
 
Key concepts to learn
- Asset Allocation: Stocks vs Bonds
- Market Cap: Large vs Mid vs Small
- Growth vs Value stocks
- Rebalancing
- Dollar Cost Averaging
- Paying off Debt vs Investing
- Retirement Accounts: Tax benefits, Roth vs Traditional, 401(k) vs IRA

1. Income: My income is ~$70k and I expect to have a lot more in retirement after 40 years of steady contributions. However because of CA taxes, $70k means Iâ€™m already in the 31.3% tax bracket (22% federal + 9.3% CA). Based on todayâ€™s tax rates, my income would have to be a whole lot higher for my future effective tax rate to be more than 31.3%, especially since Iâ€™ll likely be married. [Higher income in retirement is a pro for Roth, though itâ€™s hard to swallow paying 31.3% today thinking itâ€™d be even more in the future]

2. Location: Living in CA puts me in a very high income tax state, and who knows if Iâ€™ll end up here, or somewhere with lower taxes. It would be nice to stay in CA but anything can happen over these next 40 years. [pro for Traditional since I could only end up in an equal or a lower income tax state]

3. Future tax rates: With relatively low tax rates today and the current state of debt, itâ€™s hard to imagine taxes wonâ€™t be significantly higher 40 years from now. I feel a little risk averse on the fear of doing traditional then getting slammed by taxes in retirement. [pro for Roth because expecting future rates to be higher]

4. Pension: I have a small pension plan at my company. Nothing major but it would definitely serve to raise my retirement income. But unless I stay at this company this point is not applicable. [pro for Roth because higher retirement income if I stay with company]

5. Roth reliability: I think itâ€™s less likely but worth noting the possibility of the government finding ways to tax Roth in the future, whether itâ€™s wealth tax, sales tax, or just diminished Roth benefits. [pro for Traditional]

Background - Iâ€™m 24 with an 80K income in a HCOL area. Iâ€™m contributing 20% of my income toward retirement between a Roth IRA and Roth 401K (might switch to traditional 401K in the coming years but doing Roth for now), which equates to 6K to the IRA and 10K to the 401K, so I still have 9.5K of unused Roth 401K contributions. I donâ€™t want to increase retirement contributions beyond 20% because I feel thatâ€™s a good baseline and that I should prioritize saving for the likelihood of needing a downpayment on a home in the next 5-10 years.

Question - Since my timeline for a downpayment is 5-10 years, I figure I should be investing that money rather than holding it all in cash. Rather than using a taxable brokerage account, would it make sense to save for a down payment via increasing my Roth 401k contributions, with the intention of withdrawing that money in 5-10 years, since thereâ€™s a penalty free early withdrawal exception for first-time homebuyers? If that exception includes the non taxable Roth growth (correct me if it doesnâ€™t), then essentially I can invest without capital gains tax up until reaching my Roth 401K limit, and the downside of not being able to withdraw until age 59.5 is eliminated since this falls under one of the early withdraw exceptions.

Does my logic make sense? Is my assumption on the early withdrawal exception accurate or is there anything Iâ€™m missing?

Does high inflation incentivize holding onto debt?

I have 30K student loan debt with 4.5% interest, and Iâ€™ve always used that 4.5% number as the basis for my internal pay off debt v invest argument, i.e. pay off debt for the security of being debt free and receive a guaranteed 4.5% rate of return, or invest hoping for better returns. 

Now with inflation on the rise, it devalues the amount of debt I have and offsets the interest I owe. Iâ€™m salaried and receive annual inflation-based raises, so letâ€™s assume next year I get a 4.5% inflation raise applied to my salary, that would loosely translate to my loan being interest free in terms of real dollars right?

So now the debate becomes pay off debt for the security of being debt free or invest hoping for better returns, except now the returns just have to beat inflation or it to be net positive. Does my logic here make sense?

Edit: after reading comments I think I can more accurately summarize my viewpoints
* Inflation offsets interest on debt in terms of real dollars
* Assuming 4.5% inflation, the real value of my debt remains the same, but the nominal dollars increases which still affects me, but THIS is offset if I get the 4.5% inflation raise
* Due to the above two points, in the debate of Debt v Investing: interest rate on my debt is no longer a factor in the equation, and if I choose investing, I just need to outpace inflation for a net positive.

How to calculate personal savings rate when saving before and after tax dollars?

I know Iâ€™m splitting hairs here, but it helps me with tracking and goal setting.

Hypothetical $100k gross salary and 75k net salary. Annual savings is 10k pre-tax to 401k and 6k after-tax to Roth IRA. So what is my savings rate? Seems incorrect to combine pre-tax/after-tax and say Iâ€™m saving 16k per year, which could equate to a 16% savings rate or 21% depending on whether Iâ€™m dividing by gross or net income.

I figure the simplest and most accurate formula is to do pre-tax savings/gross income + after-tax savings/net income as follows:
* 10k pre-tax / 100k gross income = 10% savings rate
* 6k Roth / 75k net income = 8% savings rate 
* Total savings rate = 10% + 8% = 18%

Does that formula make sense? What else should I consider? While I understand itâ€™s somewhat arbitrary and Iâ€™m probably close enough, Iâ€™m happy to get granular if you are.

Order of operations, in retirement? (hypothetical)

Hey all,

Lets assume rules and brackets are like they are today, these numbers are my assumptions in 26 years for myself.

**..I am 60, MFJ and retired.**

&#x200B;

* **1.5m** in 401k that I just rolled over to a **Roth IRA (70/30 split stocks/bonds)**
* **900k** (445 in mine, 445 in my wifes- who I contribute to via the spousal Roth since she doesn't work)  **Roth IRA (100% SP 500)**
* **250k in HSA (100% SP 500**

&#x200B;

*...kid(s) are in college/finishing up, I have a 529 setup for them which should cover costs or at least a good chunk of them, so assume they're good there.*

*My wife and I can live off 65k a year. House paid off, if anything we could downsize. This lets us live life, enjoy some vaca's, etc.*

**My question is, what order should I do things? In my mind:**

1. Take out \~85k in IRA money a year which after taxes gives me that 65k I need to live life from age 60-70 or as long as I can (*put off SS until 70*).
2. I have \~25k left that I can roll over from my IRA to Roth and pay minimal taxes on to fill the 12% bracket (MFJ) and let that grow tax free for later via a conversion/ladder whatever you want to call it, Repeat step 1-2 as long as I can until the well runs dry. *All the while my Roth IRA and HSA keep growing, I use the HSA to pay any big medical expense but hoping they wont be that crazy.*
3. My IRA gets milked dry eventually because I am taking out close to 6% a year plus the \~25k I am rolling over which is basically 8%, twice the recommended amount...but instead of doing me 30 years it will do me \~15 which is probably more than I really need since SS is about to hit at 70 for wife and I. 
4. Now I am 70, have put off SS long enough. I don't have much left in the IRA so I can use that to fill lower tax brackets, wife and I are combined supposed to get 59k a year in SS by now which probably will only be taxed at 50% because I am using only \~30k in IRA a year to fill the lower brackets. I still roll over the excess like I have been until I am finally dry of IRA.
5. Now I have no IRA but my Roths have been growing forever, same with HSA and we get a lot of SS. Rest of my life I can pull out anything in Roth tax free, use SS to fill lower tax brackets, HSA for health still...

&#x200B;

Is there anything you would do different/I would be missing here?

Is my understanding of indexes vs index funds correct?

When talking about finance, investing and money indexes are a method of looking at portfolios and how well, or bad they are doing. So, to make it clear you canâ€™t directly invest in an index, but you can invest in what the index represents which are called index funds. So in theory, you can represent McDonald's (MCD), Wendyâ€™s (WEN), and Restaurant Brands International INC (QSR) as anÂ index but you wouldnâ€™t be likely to find an index fund with all three because these three companies are competing.
